<p><strong>The McKinsey Global Institute estimates</strong> that data and analytics could create approximately $1.2 trillion a year in value across the public and social sectors.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e87819e2-5f5f-49ad-a293-ec55fbadca1d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e87819e2-5f5f-49ad-a293-ec55fbadca1d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ankur Ghia, Meredith Langstaff, David Ware, and Rob Wavra, <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/accelerating-data-and-analytics-transformations-in-the-public-sector">Accelerating data and analytics transformations in the public sector</a>, McKinsey, March 18, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> The past two and half years have seen no shortage of new public-sector analytics use cases that bear out this potential value. Government entities have created real-time pandemic dashboards, conducted geospatial mapping for drawing new public transportation routes, and analyzed public sentiment to inform economic recovery investment.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body">This article is a collaborative effort by Giles Colclough, Ellen Feehan, <a href="/our-people/jessica-kahn">Jessica Kahn</a>, Saumya Singh, and Bill Yau, representing views from McKinseys Public Sector Practice.</div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>While many of these examples were born out of necessity, public-sector agencies are now embracing the impact that data-driven decision making can have on residents, employees, and other agencies. Embedding data and analytics at the core of operations can help optimize government resources by targeting them more effectively and enable civil servants to focus their efforts on activities that deliver the greatest results.</p>
<p>In this article, we examine how state and local governments could benefit from data-driven decision making, and the common obstacles an informed data strategy could overcome. We also discuss six factors that have helped public-sector agencies accelerate their data and analytics maturity.</p>
<h2>The need for data muscle in government</h2>
<!-- -->
<p>State and local governments could benefit from learning to flex data-driven decision-making muscle both internally (in and among agencies) and externally (with and for residents). Internally, it can give leaders near real-time visibility into priority measures of success to inform faster interventions when projects or priorities need attention from a given department or agency. State workers daily business resources could be enhanced to include targeted data and analytics tools that can improve efficiency and productivity in crucial areas such as outbreak response.</p>
<p>Externally, a robust government data platform could enable residents to access and control their own data (for example, in tax and state records) as well as communicate with government agencies through trusted and helpful shared tools. Local departments, community-based agencies, and faith-based agencies could also use the platform to liaise between government and residents and coordinate their outreach on initiatives that benefit the community. Feedback loops from resident-facing apps could further inform future activities taken by the state.</p>
<p>The muscle-building regimen for data-driven decision making often depends on how well data and analytics are currently used. A thorough understanding of an agencys current maturityand its place on the overall maturity spectrum (exhibit, and see sidebar Four stages of the data and analytics maturity journey)can inform a consistent routine, and skilled expansion of data and analytics tools.</p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Four stages of the data and analytics maturity journey</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Each stage in the maturity journey</strong> increases in complexity, progressing from descriptive to predictive and prescriptive analytics for public-sector agencies:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Building insights:</em> Ad hoc analytics provide clear insights in pockets of the agency. However, data is not seen as an asset or fully integrated into the front lines (not effectively used by resident-facing workers, for example). Data sharing is difficult across different levels and across organizations.</li>
    <li><em>Capturing value:</em> Strong senior leadership support exists and the agency pursues greater data and analytics capabilities. The front line uses data effectively, but data-driven decisions remain subscale across the enterprise, and agency-wide or statewide silos are unresolved.</li>
    <li> <em>Achieving scale:</em> Analytics are prioritized with dedicated resources, investment, and organizational commitment. A center of excellence pushes for data-driven decisions to occur at scale. Talent across the agency is empowered to focus on usage, adoption, and impact.</li>
    <li><em>Becoming data and analytics driven:</em> Reliable and flexible technology enables data to serve as a strategic asset. Functions integrate and siloes dissolveeven across other state agencies, regions, and third-party agencies. Insight-driven decision making and learning (both human and machine) is the norm.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>But even an informed data strategy faces inevitable challenges, from choosing the right product to ensuring new tools can integrate with existing systems. Each stage could face hurdles such as risk-averse mindsets, entrenched behaviors, infrastructure gaps, and data use agreements that reinforce silos. Some state and local agencies have overcome these challenges by implementing change programs and making investments to embed data and analytics use at the core of how they work.</p>
<p>Moreover, it can be temptingand dizzyingto consider the vast array of advanced technologies in the market in various phases of development. The global data and analytics space is evolving rapidly thanks to emerging technologies at the cutting edge of prescriptive analytics, as well as continuous innovation by industry leaders and start-ups. While some state and local governments are ready to adopt such advanced technologies, most public-sector agencies can still find opportunities to use simpler and highly accessible data tools that are more widely available.</p>
<h2>Six factors for accelerating data and analytics maturity</h2>
<p>We have identified six factors that could help accelerate data and analytics maturity, along with examples from public-sector agencies that have achieved success in this area.</p>
<h3>Build priorities around the state or agency strategy</h3>
<p>Every agencys data and analytics approach ideally aligns with and cascades from its overall strategic goals and intended public-sector impact. With so many competing priorities across a states or agencys agenda, it can be easy to lose sight of what is important and what is extraneous. A clearly articulated vision could ensure that time and effort are focused on the most important issues and in areas where analytics can meaningfully influence decisions and outcomes. A strong, clear vision could determine which specific analytics use cases could engender the greatest results and inform plans for the underlying data and technology needed to power those analytics.</p>
<p>One state, for example, ensures its data strategy focuses on specific data to solve agency and organizational challenges within identified policy areas and consistently aligns with the governors established priorities. This state also plans to invest analytics resources in a focused set of strategic priority areas such as public safety and criminal justice, housing and homelessness, workforce development, and COVID-19 recovery.</p>
<h3>Demonstrate success early to generate momentum</h3>
<p>A major data and analytics transformation can be daunting, especially if funding for the undertaking is limited. Rather than attempt to create a massive cross-agency, decade-long overhaul, leaders could start small and build momentum. Early wins could help establish proof points to celebrate and cultivate excitement across the agency. When effectively communicated across the agency, these early wins could also help catalyze more organic data and analytics transformations.</p>
<p>In one mid-Atlantic state, the Department of Health started small by focusing its data and analytics transformation efforts on the division of childhood lead exposure. The division was selected because it aligned with the departments goals related to improving child health, had relatively few interdependencies with other divisions, and possessed a highly motivated data-driven leader. Over the course of several weeks, a cross-functional team of program leaders and analytics experts aligned on their targets and key measures to identify initiatives that could deliver the greatest outcome and then conceptualized the data and analytics needed to inform interventions.</p>
<p>Dashboard views for several levels of the government (for example, the Department of Health, local health departments, and municipal, county, and state offices) were then built to incorporate these data and analytics and shared across state and local levels. The solution and the speed of delivery generated interest from other divisions within the Department of Health to pursue the same approach and leverage centralized infrastructure such as a data lake.</p>
<h3>Lead with a data and analytics center of excellence</h3>
<p>Given the complex intersection of programmatic and functional expertise needed for a data and analytics transformation, state and local leaders could consider establishing a data and analytics center of excellence (CoE). A CoE generally consists of a specialized team that, especially in early stages of data and analytics maturity, could help accelerate results through coordination and know-how. For instance, the CoE could take responsibility for developing the initial strategic plan, incorporating linkages to the agencys vision, and assembling and prioritizing a strategic road map for data and analytics. Over time, the CoE could serve a broader set of functions (see sidebar Additional functions of a data and analytics center of excellence).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Additional functions of a data and analytics center of excellence</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>A data and analytics center</strong> of excellence could serve multiple functions in an agency or across agencies over time:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Single source of truth:</em> facilitating discussions with data privacy, IT, and data owners and creating clear definitions and standards for data</li>
    <li><em>Data steward:</em> connecting dots across different agencies data sets; designing how the data is extracted, transformed, and loaded; and building institutional memory on analyses</li>
    <li><em>Road map owner:</em> refreshing priorities and capabilities to ensure continual analytics progress toward strategic outcomes </li>
    <li><em>Knowledge hub:</em> establishing a community to continually elevate best practices across agile ways of working, tools, and analytics</li>
    <li><em>Trainer:</em> educating the rest of the agency to set a baseline of data and analytics fluency</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Due to the potential breadth of its remit, a data and analytics CoE may need to assemble a diverse set of roles and capabilities, including a central analytics team leader, business analysts and translators, data scientists, data engineers, visualization experts, and back-end engineers. The exact composition may evolve over time as priorities shift, gaps in the rest of the agencies close, and new challenges emerge. There may also be additional operational design choices to consider related to roles and responsibilities, and how each agencys CoE interfaces with similar teams in other parts of the state government.</p>
<p>Connecticuts Data and Policy Analytics unit operates like an analytics CoE.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c5a573b5-0170-4892-85fe-eeb964eb3202"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c5a573b5-0170-4892-85fe-eeb964eb3202" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Data and Policy Analytics, State of Connecticut Office of Policy and Management.</span></span></span></a></span> It is a centralized group designed to support state agencies with their data and analytics needs, including open data (such as publishing and visualizations), data integration (for example, identifying data sources and data linkage or matching), analytics (such as strategy development or use cases road maps), mapping and geospatial data, best practices, and coordination and facilitation. This cross-functional team supports multiple agencies, affording a systemwide perspective on data and analytics.</p>
<h3>Scale through agile operating principles</h3>
<p>As a public-sector agency begins to accelerate across its data and analytics maturity journey, the number of use cases that must be developed, built, and scaled is likely to increase quickly. This is when the how often becomes just as important as the what, and the agency may need to consider adopting an agile operating model. This <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-five-trademarks-of-agile-organizations">approach</a> could enable teams to progress sustainably through a stream of use cases in time-boxed sprints.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a94c98bc-21f2-40e5-9237-6d1cfa518564"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a94c98bc-21f2-40e5-9237-6d1cfa518564" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-five-trademarks-of-agile-organizations">The five trademarks of agile organizations</a></em>, McKinsey, January 22, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> The model could also facilitate greater flexibility and responsiveness, attributes that are especially valuable in emergencies such as the COVID-19 pandemic.</p>
<p>In one case, the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) of a large state saw a sharp increase in fraudulent activity during the pandemic due to a host of factors, including higher rates for commercial driver services, higher prices of used vehicles, and new avenues for monetizing stolen IDs such as Pandemic Unemployment Assistance. In response, the DMVs investigations division launched a major effort to tap into the states wealth of disparate data sets in hopes of identifying risks that fraud investigators may not have been detecting.</p>
<p>To enable this, they workshopped a new operating model that focused on agility. Teams conducted rapid data engineering sprints to connect a growing portfolio of internal and external data sources.</p>
<p>Through this new way of working, the DMV was able to continuously generate new insights and delegate response measures to the appropriate parties. This enhanced use of analytics based on agile operating principles led to a more than 55 percent increase in detection of verified fraudsters, a more than 50 percent reduction in the false-positive fraud detection rate, an improved employee experience with a bench of modern tools to fight fraud, and ultimately a streamlined resident experience.</p>
<h3>Invest in a modern technology backbone</h3>
<p> A public-sector agencys ability to achieve its analytics ambitions in large part depends on adopting the appropriate technology to underpin it. However, public-sector leaders may be accustomed to infrastructure that is older, not integrated, and highly complex. For example, one state department was running approximately 125 enterprise applications across 15 divisions, the majority of which were on premises and had no method for sharing data or insights with one another. Constraints from categorical funding had compounded investment in siloed systems rather than shared technology infrastructure.</p>
<p>The state set a goal of integrating the data across departments and agencies to gain a 360-degree view of populations served by multiple public-health programs, such as immunizations and the women-infant-children (WIC) program. The states data and analytics upgrades reduced duplicate applications, which revealed opportunities to adopt enterprise-wide cloud solutions. Those solutions boosted productivity and generated cost savings. The department also used more commercial off-the-shelf and software as a service (SaaS) solutions instead of building bespoke ones.</p>
<h3>Identify and navigate structural barriers systematically</h3>
<p> Public-sector agencies routinely face structural barriers to advancing data and analytics maturity. One McKinsey Global Institute report found only 10 to 20 percent of potential value from data and analytics was captured in the public sector over a five-year period due to barriers stemming from siloed data within and across agencies as well as a lack of analytics talent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="719835dd-75e2-44ea-9a4e-6252554db481"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="719835dd-75e2-44ea-9a4e-6252554db481" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"> Value measured between 2011 to 2016 for public-sector agencies in developed markets; <a href="/capabilities/quantumblack/our-insights/the-age-of-analytics-competing-in-a-data-driven-world">The age of analytics: Competing in a data-driven world</a>, McKinsey Global Institute, December 7, 2016.</span></span></span></a></span> The public sector has a relatively harder time attracting and retaining data and analytics talent,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8d35dab1-8f07-4bff-9f14-6d3759b4aaef"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8d35dab1-8f07-4bff-9f14-6d3759b4aaef" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Danny Clark, Marcy Jacobs, Megan McConnell, and Sarah Tucker-Ray, <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/transforming-the-us-governments-approach-to-hiring-digital-talent">Transforming the US governments approach to hiring digital talent</a>, McKinsey, September 9, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> and contracts often require a multiyear commitment, preventing agile technology builds and the incorporation of best-of-breed technology and data services vendors. Moreover, funding to advance data and analytics may be earmarked for specific programmatic use cases instead of for building foundational infrastructure.</p>
<p>Acknowledging and navigating these institutional barriers systematically could prove pivotal, especially at early stages of the data and analytics maturity journey.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c4579175-d814-4c90-8644-c24f204a6855"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c4579175-d814-4c90-8644-c24f204a6855" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ankur Ghia, Meredith Langstaff, David Ware, and Rob Wavra, <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/accelerating-data-and-analytics-transformations-in-the-public-sector">Accelerating data and analytics transformations in the public sector</a>, McKinsey, March 18, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> For example, one state set up novel partnerships with local academic institutions and established the role of a rotating data scientist training fellow to secure a pool of motivated, highly trained specialist talent. Another states analytics CoE established a learning program for analysts with a field-and-forum journey that supported analysts at varying capability levels to enhance their skills.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dccdc39b-bfb7-477b-b565-7b1cd9b53b23"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dccdc39b-bfb7-477b-b565-7b1cd9b53b23" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jessica Kahn, <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/lessons-in-leadership-using-data-to-drive-public-health-decisions">Lessons in leadership: Using data to drive public-health decisions</a>, McKinsey, August 16, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>These six factors suggest an approach that agencies might take regardless of their current capabilities to ensure analytics can drive meaningful insights, decisions, and results.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>In our experience, agencies that acknowledge, highlight, and systematically review barriers to data and analytics maturity are more likely to overcome them. Agencies may face different challenges, including access to talent, data governance, contracting restrictions, or organizational design. Once they clearly identify which obstacles are specific to their paths, they can develop plans to overcome them. This includes getting buy-in and sponsorship from senior leadership.</p>
<hr>
<p>These six factors can help jump-start progress for public-sector agencies looking to accelerate their capabilities and advance in data and analytics maturity. These factors in no way diminish the complexities of specific domains and contexts that public-sector agencies may have to face; instead, they suggest an approach that agencies might take regardless of their current capabilities to ensure analytics can drive meaningful insights, decisions, and results.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid data and analytics maturity in the US public sector"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Data analytics: Accelerating maturity in the US public sector"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"US public-sector agencies that have quickly and effectively advanced data and analytics capabilities offer lessons on how to embed data-driven decision making at all levels of government."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Some US public sector agencies advanced data and analytics capabilities quickly and effectively, which could pave the way to embed  data-driven decision making at all levels of government. "},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-11-21T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe McKinsey Global Institute estimates\u003c/strong\u003e that data and analytics could create approximately $1.2 trillion a year in value across the public and social sectors.[[Footnote 1]] The past two and half years have seen no shortage of new public-sector analytics use cases that bear out this potential value. Government entities have created real-time pandemic dashboards, conducted geospatial mapping for drawing new public transportation routes, and analyzed public sentiment to inform economic recovery investment.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eWhile many of these examples were born out of necessity, public-sector agencies are now embracing the impact that data-driven decision making can have on residents, employees, and other agencies. Embedding data and analytics at the core of operations can help optimize government resources by targeting them more effectively and enable civil servants to focus their efforts on activities that deliver the greatest results.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this article, we examine how state and local governments could benefit from data-driven decision making, and the common obstacles an informed data strategy could overcome. We also discuss six factors that have helped public-sector agencies accelerate their data and analytics maturity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe need for data muscle in government\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eState and local governments could benefit from learning to flex data-driven decision-making muscle both internally (in and among agencies) and externally (with and for residents). Internally, it can give leaders near real-time visibility into priority measures of success to inform faster interventions when projects or priorities need attention from a given department or agency. State workers\u0026rsquo; daily business resources could be enhanced to include targeted data and analytics tools that can improve efficiency and productivity in crucial areas such as outbreak response.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExternally, a robust government data platform could enable residents to access and control their own data (for example, in tax and state records) as well as communicate with government agencies through trusted and helpful shared tools. Local departments, community-based agencies, and faith-based agencies could also use the platform to liaise between government and residents and coordinate their outreach on initiatives that benefit the community. Feedback loops from resident-facing apps could further inform future activities taken by the state.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe muscle-building regimen for data-driven decision making often depends on how well data and analytics are currently used. A thorough understanding of an agency\u0026rsquo;s current maturity\u0026mdash;and its place on the overall maturity spectrum (exhibit, and see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Four stages of the data and analytics maturity journey\u0026rdquo;)\u0026mdash;can inform a consistent routine, and skilled expansion of data and analytics tools.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eBut even an informed data strategy faces inevitable challenges, from choosing the right product to ensuring new tools can integrate with existing systems. Each stage could face hurdles such as risk-averse mindsets, entrenched behaviors, infrastructure gaps, and data use agreements that reinforce silos. Some state and local agencies have overcome these challenges by implementing change programs and making investments to embed data and analytics use at the core of how they work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMoreover, it can be tempting\u0026mdash;and dizzying\u0026mdash;to consider the vast array of advanced technologies in the market in various phases of development. The global data and analytics space is evolving rapidly thanks to emerging technologies at the cutting edge of prescriptive analytics, as well as continuous innovation by industry leaders and start-ups. While some state and local governments are ready to adopt such advanced technologies, most public-sector agencies can still find opportunities to use simpler and highly accessible data tools that are more widely available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSix factors for accelerating data and analytics maturity\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe have identified six factors that could help accelerate data and analytics maturity, along with examples from public-sector agencies that have achieved success in this area.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBuild priorities around the state or agency strategy\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEvery agency\u0026rsquo;s data and analytics approach ideally aligns with and cascades from its overall strategic goals and intended public-sector impact. With so many competing priorities across a state\u0026rsquo;s or agency\u0026rsquo;s agenda, it can be easy to lose sight of what is important and what is extraneous. A clearly articulated vision could ensure that time and effort are focused on the most important issues and in areas where analytics can meaningfully influence decisions and outcomes. A strong, clear vision could determine which specific analytics use cases could engender the greatest results and inform plans for the underlying data and technology needed to power those analytics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne state, for example, ensures its data strategy focuses on specific data to solve agency and organizational challenges within identified policy areas and consistently aligns with the governor\u0026rsquo;s established priorities. This state also plans to invest analytics resources in a focused set of strategic priority areas such as public safety and criminal justice, housing and homelessness, workforce development, and COVID-19 recovery.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDemonstrate success early to generate momentum\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA major data and analytics transformation can be daunting, especially if funding for the undertaking is limited. Rather than attempt to create a massive cross-agency, decade-long overhaul, leaders could start small and build momentum. Early wins could help establish proof points to celebrate and cultivate excitement across the agency. When effectively communicated across the agency, these early wins could also help catalyze more organic data and analytics transformations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn one mid-Atlantic state, the Department of Health started small by focusing its data and analytics transformation efforts on the division of childhood lead exposure. The division was selected because it aligned with the department\u0026rsquo;s goals related to improving child health, had relatively few interdependencies with other divisions, and possessed a highly motivated data-driven leader. Over the course of several weeks, a cross-functional team of program leaders and analytics experts aligned on their targets and key measures to identify initiatives that could deliver the greatest outcome and then conceptualized the data and analytics needed to inform interventions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDashboard views for several levels of the government (for example, the Department of Health, local health departments, and municipal, county, and state offices) were then built to incorporate these data and analytics and shared across state and local levels. The solution and the speed of delivery generated interest from other divisions within the Department of Health to pursue the same approach and leverage centralized infrastructure such as a data lake.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eLead with a data and analytics center of excellence\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven the complex intersection of programmatic and functional expertise needed for a data and analytics transformation, state and local leaders could consider establishing a data and analytics center of excellence (CoE). A CoE generally consists of a specialized team that, especially in early stages of data and analytics maturity, could help accelerate results through coordination and know-how. For instance, the CoE could take responsibility for developing the initial strategic plan, incorporating linkages to the agency\u0026rsquo;s vision, and assembling and prioritizing a strategic road map for data and analytics. Over time, the CoE could serve a broader set of functions (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Additional functions of a data and analytics center of excellence\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eDue to the potential breadth of its remit, a data and analytics CoE may need to assemble a diverse set of roles and capabilities, including a central analytics team leader, business analysts and translators, data scientists, data engineers, visualization experts, and back-end engineers. The exact composition may evolve over time as priorities shift, gaps in the rest of the agencies close, and new challenges emerge. There may also be additional operational design choices to consider related to roles and responsibilities, and how each agency\u0026rsquo;s CoE interfaces with similar teams in other parts of the state government.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConnecticut\u0026rsquo;s Data and Policy Analytics unit operates like an analytics CoE.[[Footnote 2]] It is a centralized group designed to support state agencies with their data and analytics needs, including open data (such as publishing and visualizations), data integration (for example, identifying data sources and data linkage or matching), analytics (such as strategy development or use cases road maps), mapping and geospatial data, best practices, and coordination and facilitation. This cross-functional team supports multiple agencies, affording a systemwide perspective on data and analytics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eScale through agile operating principles\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a public-sector agency begins to accelerate across its data and analytics maturity journey, the number of use cases that must be developed, built, and scaled is likely to increase quickly. This is when the \u0026ldquo;how\u0026rdquo; often becomes just as important as the \u0026ldquo;what,\u0026rdquo; and the agency may need to consider adopting an agile operating model. This \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-five-trademarks-of-agile-organizations\"\u003eapproach\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;could enable teams to progress sustainably through a stream of use cases in time-boxed sprints.[[Footnote 3]] The model could also facilitate greater flexibility and responsiveness, attributes that are especially valuable in emergencies such as the COVID-19 pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn one case, the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) of a large state saw a sharp increase in fraudulent activity during the pandemic due to a host of factors, including higher rates for commercial driver services, higher prices of used vehicles, and new avenues for monetizing stolen IDs such as Pandemic Unemployment Assistance. In response, the DMV\u0026rsquo;s investigations division launched a major effort to tap into the state\u0026rsquo;s wealth of disparate data sets in hopes of identifying risks that fraud investigators may not have been detecting.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo enable this, they workshopped a new operating model that focused on agility. Teams conducted rapid data engineering sprints to connect a growing portfolio of internal and external data sources.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThrough this new way of working, the DMV was able to continuously generate new insights and delegate response measures to the appropriate parties. This enhanced use of analytics based on agile operating principles led to a more than 55 percent increase in detection of verified fraudsters, a more than 50 percent reduction in the false-positive fraud detection rate, an improved employee experience with a bench of modern tools to fight fraud, and ultimately a streamlined resident experience.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInvest in a modern technology backbone\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e A public-sector agency\u0026rsquo;s ability to achieve its analytics ambitions in large part depends on adopting the appropriate technology to underpin it. However, public-sector leaders may be accustomed to infrastructure that is older, not integrated, and highly complex. For example, one state department was running approximately 125 enterprise applications across 15 divisions, the majority of which were on premises and had no method for sharing data or insights with one another. Constraints from categorical funding had compounded investment in siloed systems rather than shared technology infrastructure.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe state set a goal of integrating the data across departments and agencies to gain a 360-degree view of populations served by multiple public-health programs, such as immunizations and the women-infant-children (WIC) program. The state\u0026rsquo;s data and analytics upgrades reduced duplicate applications, which revealed opportunities to adopt enterprise-wide cloud solutions. Those solutions boosted productivity and generated cost savings. The department also used more commercial off-the-shelf and software as a service (SaaS) solutions instead of building bespoke ones.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eIdentify and navigate structural barriers systematically\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e Public-sector agencies routinely face structural barriers to advancing data and analytics maturity. One McKinsey Global Institute report found only 10 to 20 percent of potential value from data and analytics was captured in the public sector over a five-year period due to barriers stemming from siloed data within and across agencies as well as a lack of analytics talent.[[Footnote 4]] The public sector has a relatively harder time attracting and retaining data and analytics talent,[[Footnote 5]] and contracts often require a multiyear commitment, preventing agile technology builds and the incorporation of best-of-breed technology and data services vendors. Moreover, funding to advance data and analytics may be earmarked for specific programmatic use cases instead of for building foundational infrastructure.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAcknowledging and navigating these institutional barriers systematically could prove pivotal, especially at early stages of the data and analytics maturity journey.[[Footnote 6]] For example, one state set up novel partnerships with local academic institutions and established the role of a rotating data scientist training fellow to secure a pool of motivated, highly trained specialist talent. Another state\u0026rsquo;s analytics CoE established a learning program for analysts with a field-and-forum journey that supported analysts at varying capability levels to enhance their skills.[[Footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Pullquote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn our experience, agencies that acknowledge, highlight, and systematically review barriers to data and analytics maturity are more likely to overcome them. Agencies may face different challenges, including access to talent, data governance, contracting restrictions, or organizational design. Once they clearly identify which obstacles are specific to their paths, they can develop plans to overcome them. This includes getting buy-in and sponsorship from senior leadership.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese six factors can help jump-start progress for public-sector agencies looking to accelerate their capabilities and advance in data and analytics maturity. These factors in no way diminish the complexities of specific domains and contexts that public-sector agencies may have to face; instead, they suggest an approach that agencies might take regardless of their current capabilities to ensure analytics can drive meaningful insights, decisions, and stage in the maturity journey\u003c/strong\u003e increases in complexity, progressing from descriptive to predictive and prescriptive analytics for public-sector agencies:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBuilding insights:\u003c/em\u003e Ad hoc analytics provide clear insights in pockets of the agency. However, data is not seen as an asset or fully integrated into the front lines (not effectively used by resident-facing workers, for example). Data sharing is difficult across different levels and across organizations.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCapturing value:\u003c/em\u003e Strong senior leadership support exists and the agency pursues greater data and analytics capabilities. The front line uses data effectively, but data-driven decisions remain subscale across the enterprise, and agency-wide or statewide silos are unresolved.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e \u003cem\u003eAchieving scale:\u003c/em\u003e Analytics are prioritized with dedicated resources, investment, and organizational commitment. A center of excellence pushes for data-driven decisions to occur at scale. Talent across the agency is empowered to focus on usage, adoption, and impact.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBecoming data and analytics driven:\u003c/em\u003e Reliable and flexible technology enables data to serve as a strategic asset. Functions integrate and siloes dissolve\u0026mdash;even across other state agencies, regions, and third-party agencies. Insight-driven decision making and learning (both human and machine) is the norm.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Four
